channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills Soldier in Egypt’s Sinai
item.description: One Egyptian soldier was killed and at least seven more people wounded in two suicide attacks in South Sinai on Friday and a policeman died in a Cairo bomb attack, official sources said, in the latest round of violence ahead of elections due in May.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Train Accident Leaves Scores Injured in Seoul
item.description: A train pulling into a subway station on Friday smashed into the back of another train that had stopped for a mechanical problem, injuring at least 170 passengers.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Seoul Metro, which operates the subway line, said it was investigating the collision.

item.title: Kerry in South Sudan to Seek an End to Fighting
item.description: The American secretary of state arrived Friday on an urgent mission to try to stop the violence that has killed thousands and is ripping the new nation apart.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Salva Kiir Mayardit of South Sudan, right, greeted U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry in Juba, South Sudan, on Friday.

item.title: An Unlikely Indian Political Star’s Latest Crusade
item.description: Arvind Kejriwal is taking on Narendra Modi, widely expected to be India’s next prime minister, in Varanasi, a bastion of strength for Mr. Modi’s party.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Adversaries Report Clashes in Key Ukrainian City
item.description: Forces loyal to the interim government said an assault to dislodge separatists in Slovyansk entered an “active phase” in the early hours of Friday.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Interest Grows in Animal Testing Alternatives
item.description: Now that China is planning to loosen its animal testing requirement, a government training program in alternative testing methods is so popular it has had to turn away applicants.
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Criticizes U.S. Terrorism Report
item.description: Chinese officials said the United States wrongly played down China’s counterterrorism efforts and was too hesitant to label attacks on Chinese soil as terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Mourners lit candles outside the Kunming Railway Station, the site in March of a knifing attack that killed 29 people and wounded more than 140.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Online, a Censored Reaction to Urumqi Bombing
item.description: As news spread of the explosion in Xinjiang, home to mostly Muslim ethnic Uighurs, the state said it would “struggle” against terrorism, and some members of the public deplored the fading of ethnic harmony.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Paramilitary police stand guard at the South Railway Station in Urumqi, where a bomb and knife attack on Wednesday left three people dead and 79 wounded.

item.title: So Far, U.S. Sanctions Over Ukraine May Be Inflicting Only Limited Pain on Russia
item.description: The real effects of the United States’ sanctions on Russia over its intervention in Ukraine appear to be more psychological than tangible, economic specialists say.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Deadly Explosion Rocks Capital
item.description: A car bomb exploded on a busy road in the capital, Abuja, on Thursday night, killing at least 12 people and wounding 19, officials and witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: North Korea: Activity at a Missile Site
item.description: New commercial satellite imagery shows that North Korea is expanding its main rocket-launching site and testing engines of what is believed to be its first road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missile.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: Greenpeace Stymied
item.description: Dutch police officers stormed a Greenpeace ship on Thursday and ended the efforts of environmental activists to block a Russian tanker carrying Arctic Ocean oil from mooring at Rotterdam Port.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 2
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Friday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A polling officer marking the finger of a voter with indelible ink at a polling station on the outskirts of Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Heinous Crime, Secret Histories and a Sinn Fein Leader’s Arrest
item.description: The arrest of Gerry Adams on Wednesday came after officials subpoenaed interviews from a Boston College oral history project whose subjects had been promised confidentiality.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
item.media:description: Jean McConville, left, with three of her 10 children. She was abducted in 1972 and murdered.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Obama Visit, Planned Naval Drills With Russia Reported
item.description: Shortly after President Obama concluded his four-nation Asia trip, a Chinese newspaper reported that Russia and China would hold joint naval exercises near disputed islands in the East China Sea in a challenge to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A Japanese Coast Guard vessel, left, sailed alongside a Chinese surveillance ship near the islands Japan calls the Senkaku and China the Diaoyu.

item.title: Looming Energy Crisis Again Confronts Egypt’s Leaders
item.description: International energy companies say that Egypt has failed to pay them for pumping its petroleum, which has created a vicious circle of nonpayment, noninvestment and diminishing production.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and STANLEY REED

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q & A: Jeffrey Wasserstrom on History, Dissent and the Power of May 4 in China
item.description: Jeffrey Wasserstrom, a history professor at the University of California, Irvine, who has studied student protests in China, discusses the history of May 4 and whether protesters might rise again.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Students in Tiananmen Square on May 4, 1989, the anniversary of the 1919 student demonstrations that began as a protest against terms of the Treaty of Versailles and developed into a broad movement for national renewal.

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Airstrike at a Bustling Market in Syria
item.description: At least 33 people were killed and many others were wounded by airstrikes at an outdoor market in Aleppo just a day after an airstrike on an elementary school killed 20.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Wounded children after an attack in Aleppo on Thursday.

item.title: Israeli Military Officials Caught Off Guard by a ‘Digital Rebellion’
item.description: Israeli Defense Forces officials were caught off guard by the online outcry over a disciplinary case.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: At Least 3 Die in Collapse of Gold Mine
item.description: The collapse of the illegal gold mine occurred late Wednesday night in western Colombia, and rescuers were searching for other miners believed to be missing.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: U.S. and Germany Fail to Reach a Deal on Spying
item.description: The effort to reach an accord began after it was disclosed last year that the National Security Agency was tapping Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphone.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel will meet with President Obama in Washington on Friday.

item.title: Florida Advances Tuition Aid for Children Brought to U.S. Illegally
item.description: The legislation’s passage is a sign that Florida’s conservative Legislature and Republican governor are intensifying efforts to woo Hispanic voters.
item.dc:creator: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ
item.media:credit: Mark Wallheiser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrations broke out in the Florida Senate gallery Thursday as the body voted to make students who were brought to the United States illegally eligible for in-state tuition.

item.title: Caught Again on Camera, Rob Ford Leaves for Treatment
item.description: The mayor of Toronto quietly exited his home and entered rehab after a video surfaced that appeared to show him smoking crack.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hunger Striker Ends Fast, but Not Fight, Against Nuclear Power in Taiwan
item.description: A former head of Taiwan’s Democratic Progressive Party thanked protesters for their campaign against a new nuclear power plant and asked them to continue to push for the closure of three others.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Lin Yi-hsiung during his weeklong hunger strike to stop construction on Taiwan's No. 4 nuclear power plant.

item.title: Netanyahu Plans to Promote Legislation on Jewish State Designation
item.description: The move comes as an apparent response to Palestinians’ rejection of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s demand for recognition of Israel as a Jewish state during peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
